column4: P: Therapist provided psycho-education (e.g., directive education about the traumatic event, normal reactiosn to trauma, etc.; education to instill hope)
column5: PSYCHOEDUCATION: Therapist provided psycho-education (e.g., directive education about the traumatic event, normal reactions to trauma, etc.; education to instill hope)

column4: General info re: abuse, trauma; specific info re: trauma child experienced (GE) and the child's reactions to his/her personal experience of the trauma
column5: General info re: abuse, trauma; specific info re: trauma child experienced (GE) and the child's reactions to his/her personal experience of the trauma

column4: Common emotional, behavioral, and physiological responses.
column5: Common emotional, behavioral, and physiological responses.

column4: Info about child's symptoms and diagnosis.
column5: Info about child's symptoms and diagnosis.

column4: Description of components of TF-CBT, session structure, treatment length
column5: Description of components of TF-CBT, session structure, treatment length

column4: Engaged family (e.g., found out what child liked, what motivates the family, etc.)
column5: Engaged family (e.g., found out what child liked, what motivates the family, etc.)

column4: P: Therapist provided parenting skills (e.g., praise, selective attention, time out, bx mng plans); ask parent about their reactions to the child's traumatic experience
column5: PARENTING: Therapist provided parenting skills (e.g., praise, selective attention, time out, bx mng plans); ask parent about their reactions to the child's traumatic experience

column4: R: Therapist explained the physiology of relaxation and rationale for relaxation techniques; instructed on methods of relaxation
column5: RELAXATION: Therapist explained the physiology of relaxation and rationale for relaxation techniques; instructed on methods of relaxation

column4: Discuss ways that relaxation skills can help child with trauma reactions (GE); suggest that child use relaxation skills when they have trauma reminders
column5: Discuss ways that relaxation skills can help child with trauma reactions (GE); suggest that child use relaxation skills when they have trauma reminders

column4: A: Therapist assisted child in accurately identifying their feelings, and various ways of regulating their emotions (e.g., imagery, thought stopping, positive self-talk)
column5: AFFECT REGULATION: Therapist assisted child in accurately identifying their feelings, and various ways of regulating their emotions (e.g., imagery, thought stopping, positive self-talk)

column4: Accurately identify and express a variety of feelings (positive and negative, in youth's words) (e.g. feelings brainstorm, Color My World, etc.)
column5: Accurately identify and express a variety of feelings (positive and negative, in youth's words) (e.g. feelings brainstorm, Color My World, etc.)

column4: Link feelings to situations, body and facial expressions
column5: Link feelings to situations, body and facial expressions

column4: Teach how to rate intensity levels of emotions (e.g. SUDS, feeling thermometer)
column5: Teach how to rate intensity levels of emotions (e.g. SUDS, feeling thermometer)

column4: Teach skills of managing emotions and difficult affective states (e.g. positive self-talk, enhancing child's sense of safety, etc.)
column5: Teach skills of managing emotions and difficult affective states (e.g. positive self-talk, enhancing child's sense of safety, etc.)

column4: Teach skills to identify/cope with array of feelings associated with trauma (GE)
column5: Teach skills to identify/cope with array of feelings associated with trauma (GE)

column4: C: Therapist reviewed skill of cognitive coping
column5: COGNITIVE COPING: Therapist reviewed skill of cognitive coping

column4: Educate child on the distinction and relationship between thoughts, feelings and actions (e.g. acknowledge internal dialogues; introduce cognitive triangle)
column5: Educate child on the distinction and relationship between thoughts, feelings and actions (e.g. acknowledge internal dialogues; introduce cognitive triangle)

column4: Help the child generate alternative thoughts that are more accurate or helpful, in order to feel differently; discuss how to apply to real life
column5: Help the child generate alternative thoughts that are more accurate or helpful, in order to feel differently; discuss how to apply to real life

column4: T: Therapist worked on a trauma narrative (TN) the child (GE)
column5: TRAUMA NARRATIVE/COGNITIVE PROCESSING: Therapist worked on a trauma narrative (TN) the child (GE)

column4: Introduce rationale for TN; initiate TN (e.g. title page, timeline/table of contents)
column5: Introduce rationale for TN; initiate TN (e.g. title page, timeline/table of contents)

column4: Encourage child, in calibrated increments, to include more details of trauma
column5: Encourage child, in calibrated increments, to include more details of trauma

column4: Re-read the TN at the beginning of each session (GE)
column5: Re-read the TN at the beginning of each session (GE)

column4: Ask about and add in thoughts and feelings throughout the TN
column5: Ask about and add in thoughts and feelings throughout the TN

column4: Include worst memory/worst moment
column5: Include worst memory/worst moment

column4: Use cognitive processing techniques to modify distortions throughout the TN
column5: Use cognitive processing techniques to modify distortions throughout the TN

column4: Include piece on making meaning (e.g. what they've learned, how they grew)
column5: Include piece on making meaning (e.g. what they've learned, how they grew)

column4: As TN develops, read each new draft to supportive caregiver in collateral sessions
column5: As TN develops, read each new draft to supportive caregiver in collateral sessions

column4: I: Therapist developed in-vivo desensitization plan for generalized avoidant behaviors
column5: IN-VIVO DESENSITIZATION: Therapist developed in-vivo desensitization plan for generalized avoidant behaviors

column4: C: Conjoint child-parent session: sharing trauma narrative with parent/caregiver
column5: CONJOINT: Conjoint child-parent session: sharing trauma narrative with parent/caregiver

column4: Prepare caregiver and child separately for joint session in which TN is shared
column5: Prepare caregiver and child separately for joint session in which TN is shared

column4: Hold joint session (e.g., re-read TN, model praise, discuss questions prepared by both child and caregiver, praise and celebrate progress made)
column5: Hold joint session (e.g., re-read TN, model praise, discuss questions prepared by both child and caregiver, praise and celebrate progress made)

column4: E: Therapist addressed child's sense of safety (e.g. safety skills and safety plan)
column5: ENHANCING SAFETY: Therapist addressed child's sense of safety (e.g. safety skills and safety plan)

column4: Teach personal safety skills and assertive communication; increase awareness
column5: Teach personal safety skills and assertive communication; increase awareness

column4: Teach problem-solving skills and/or social skills as needed by the child
